qas.question: What were the effects of affirmative action on universities according to the study done by the AAUP?

answers.text: positive effects on the educational outcomes and experiences of college students

qas.question: What did a study claim about the beliefs of faculty members on increased diversity?

answers.text: helps students to reach the essential goals of a college education

qas.question: Who supposedly suffers no detrimental effects from classroom diversity?
In which year did the AAUP release their study?

plausible_answers.text: positive effects on the educational outcomes and experiences of college students as well as the teaching of faculty members

qas.question: What were the effects of affirmative action on universities according to the study done by the AALP?

plausible_answers.text: helps students to reach the essential goals of a college education

qas.question: What did a study claim about the beliefs of faculty members on decreased diversity?
Who supposedly suffers a lot of detrimental effects from classroom diversity?
In which year did the ALUP release their study?

context: In the year <a4_0>2000<a4_0/>, according to a study by <a0_0><b5_0>American Association of University Professors<b5_0/><a0_0/> (AAUP), affirmative action promoted diversity within colleges and universities. This has been shown to have <a1_0><b6_0>positive effects on the educational outcomes and experiences of college students<a1_0/> as well as the teaching of faculty members<b6_0/>. According to a study by Geoffrey Maruyama and José F. Moreno, the results showed that faculty members believed diversity <a2_0><b7_0>helps students to reach the essential goals of a college education<b7_0/><a2_0/>, <a3_0><b8_0>Caucasian students<b8_0/><a3_0/> suffer no detrimental effects from classroom diversity, and that attention to multicultural learning improves the ability of colleges and universities to accomplish their missions. Furthermore, a diverse population of students offers unique perspectives in order to challenge preconceived notions through exposure to the experiences and ideas of others. According to Professor Gurin of the University of Michigan, skills such as "perspective-taking, acceptance of differences, a willingness and capacity to find commonalities among differences, acceptance of conflict as normal, conflict resolution, participation in democracy, and interest in the wider social world" can potentially be developed in college while being exposed to heterogeneous group of students. In addition, broadening perspectives helps students confront personal and substantive stereotypes and fosters discussion about racial and ethnic issues in a classroom setting. Furthermore, the <b9_0>2000<b9_0/> AAUP study states that having a diversity of views leads to a better discussion and greater understanding among the students on issues of race, tolerance, fairness, etc.
